title: Understanding Derivatives: A Deep Dive into Calculus

sections.heading: Introduction to Derivatives
sections.teaching_goal: Students understand derivatives as the slope of tangent lines and instantaneous rate of change

key_moments.description: Show parabola f(x) = x² with secant line becoming tangent line at x = 3
visuals: Blue parabola curve f(x) = x² on coordinate plane (-5 to 5, 0 to 25)
Two points on curve: (2, 4) and (4, 16) connected by green secant line
Point (3, 9) marked with red dot
Red tangent line at x = 3 with slope = 6
animation_sequence: Step 1 (3s): Draw blue parabola f(x) = x²
Step 2 (2s): Show green secant line through (2,4) and (4,16)
Step 3 (5s): Gradually move second point closer to (3,9), secant line approaches tangent
Step 4 (3s): Final red tangent line appears at x = 3
Step 5 (2s): Label 'slope = 6' appears next to tangent line

key_moments.description: Present limit definition with variables clearly labeled
visuals: Large centered equation in white text
Variable definitions in yellow boxes below equation
Small diagram showing h approaching 0
animation_sequence: Step 1 (3s): Write limit definition equation
Step 2 (4s): Highlight each variable with colored boxes
Step 3 (3s): Show f(x) = function, h = small increment, x = point
Step 4 (2s): Emphasize 'as h approaches 0'
Step 5 (3s): Connect back to tangent line concept

key_moments.moment: Calculate derivative of x² at x = 3
visuals: Left side: step-by-step algebraic work in white text
Right side: geometric interpretation on coordinate plane
Green intermediate steps, blue final answer
animation_sequence: Step 1 (3s): Substitute x = 3 into limit definition
Step 2 (3s): Expand (3+h)² = 9 + 6h + h²
Step 3 (3s): Simplify numerator to 6h + h²
Step 4 (3s): Factor out h: h(6 + h)/h = 6 + h
Step 5 (3s): Evaluate limit as h→0: result is 6
Step 6 (5s): Highlight final answer f'(3) = 6 in blue box

sections.misconception_addressed: Derivatives are not just slopes - they represent instantaneous rate of change
sections.student_question_answered: Why use limits instead of just calculating slope between two points?

sections.heading: Rules of Differentiation
sections.teaching_goal: Students can apply power rule and product rule to find derivatives efficiently

key_moments.description: Show power rule formula and apply to multiple examples
visuals: Power rule formula in large orange text at top
Three examples in columns: x³, x⁵, x⁻²
Step-by-step application with arrows showing n and n-1
Results highlighted in green boxes
animation_sequence: Step 1 (3s): Display power rule formula
Step 2 (2s): Show three example functions: x³, x⁵, x⁻²
Step 3 (5s): Apply rule to x³: 3x² with arrows showing 3→coefficient, 3-1=2
Step 4 (4s): Apply to x⁵: 5x⁴
Step 5 (4s): Apply to x⁻²: -2x⁻³
Step 6 (2s): Highlight all results in green

key_moments.description: Introduce product rule with clear variable identification
visuals: Product rule formula centered in purple text
Two function boxes: u(x) in blue, v(x) in red
Derivative arrows: u'(x) and v'(x) in corresponding colors
Formula breakdown with color coding
animation_sequence: Step 1 (3s): Write product rule formula
Step 2 (3s): Color-code u in blue, v in red
Step 3 (3s): Show u' and v' with derivative arrows
Step 4 (3s): Highlight two terms: u'v and uv'
Step 5 (3s): Emphasize addition between terms

key_moments.description: Complete worked example showing each step of product rule application
visuals: Function f(x) = x²sin(x) at top
Left column: identify u = x², v = sin(x) in colored boxes
Middle column: find derivatives u' = 2x, v' = cos(x)
Right column: apply formula step by step
Final answer in highlighted box
animation_sequence: Step 1 (3s): Show f(x) = x²sin(x)
Step 2 (3s): Identify u = x² (blue box), v = sin(x) (red box)
Step 3 (3s): Find u' = 2x, v' = cos(x)
Step 4 (4s): Apply formula: u'v = 2x·sin(x)
Step 5 (4s): Add uv' = x²·cos(x)
Step 6 (3s): Final result: f'(x) = 2x sin(x) + x² cos(x) in yellow box

sections.misconception_addressed: Product rule is NOT just multiplying the derivatives - must use the specific formula
sections.student_question_answered: Why can't we just differentiate each part separately in a product?

sections.heading: Applications of Derivatives
sections.teaching_goal: Students understand real-world applications of derivatives in physics and optimization

key_moments.description: Show relationship between position function and its derivatives
visuals: Three graphs stacked vertically showing s(t), v(t), a(t)
Position graph: s(t) = t² - 2t + 5 (blue curve)
Velocity graph: v(t) = 2t - 2 (red line)
Acceleration graph: a(t) = 2 (green horizontal line)
Arrows showing derivative relationships between graphs
animation_sequence: Step 1 (4s): Draw position curve s(t) = t² - 2t + 5
Step 2 (3s): Label axes: time (0 to 4), position (0 to 10)
Step 3 (5s): Show velocity v(t) = 2t - 2 as derivative
Step 4 (3s): Draw velocity line graph below position
Step 5 (5s): Show acceleration a(t) = 2 as second derivative
Step 6 (3s): Draw constant acceleration line
Step 7 (2s): Highlight derivative arrows between all three graphs

key_moments.description: Use derivatives to find maximum of profit function P(x) = -x² + 8x - 12
visuals: Profit function graph: downward parabola in green
Critical point marked with red dot at x = 4
Derivative P'(x) = -2x + 8 shown as equation
Horizontal line at P'(x) = 0 intersecting at x = 4
Maximum profit value P(4) = 4 highlighted in yellow box
animation_sequence: Step 1 (4s): Draw profit parabola P(x) = -x² + 8x - 12
Step 2 (3s): Label axes: quantity (0 to 8), profit (-15 to 5)
Step 3 (4s): Show derivative P'(x) = -2x + 8
Step 4 (4s): Explain critical points where P'(x) = 0
Step 5 (5s): Solve -2x + 8 = 0, get x = 4
Step 6 (3s): Mark critical point (4, 4) with red dot
Step 7 (4s): Calculate P(4) = -16 + 32 - 12 = 4
Step 8 (3s): Highlight maximum profit of 4 units at x = 4

sections.misconception_addressed: Derivatives aren't just abstract math - they solve real optimization problems
sections.student_question_answered: How do derivatives help find maximum and minimum values in real situations?

overall_flow: Introduction to derivative concept → Computational rules → Real-world applications
key_teaching_moments: Derivatives as slopes of tangent lines
